question_text: Based on the provided review paper, explain how the relative velocity between air and fuel jets affects flame height in turbulent inverse jet diffusion flames (IJDF), and describe the underlying mixing mechanisms responsible for this relationship.
standard_answer: In turbulent inverse jet diffusion flames (IJDF), the relative velocity between the central air jet and annular fuel jet significantly influences flame height through enhanced mixing mechanisms. According to the review paper, 'In the case of turbulent IJDF, the higher relative velocity (Ve) between air and fuel jets ensures better fuel entrainment and enhanced mixing, resulting in shorter visible flame height than the NJDF.' This occurs because increased relative velocity amplifies shear-induced turbulence at the air-fuel interface, which intensifies the entrainment of the annular fuel jet by the central air jet. The enhanced turbulent mixing accelerates the scalar dissipation rates, promoting faster fuel-air mixing and reducing the distance required for complete combustion. Consequently, the flame height decreases as the relative velocity increases. The paper further notes that 'The air-fuel velocity ratio does not consider the effect of fuel/oxidizer density ratio in describing the extent of fuel-oxidizer mixing in IJDF,' suggesting that while velocity ratio is a key parameter, momentum considerations incorporating density effects may provide a more comprehensive characterization of mixing efficiency in these flames.
